Award.AwardTitle: Japan-MIT Nano-Bio Symposium for young research exchange at MIT, March 29th, 2013

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal is to run a workshop entitled MIT-Japan Nano-Bio Symposium. A group of young Japanese bio-sensor scientists are being hosted at MIT. The proposed conference will improve US exposure of some of the most promising Japanese scientists in the field of biosensors. This conference will help form bridges between young biosensors and nanotechnology scientists in the two countries. This program will broaden horizons of US scientists and spark further travel, cross-dissemination and ultimately will bring scientists from the two countries closer together. This conference may also result in collaborative projects between scientists from two countries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Every year, a group of young and promising scientists and engineers from Japan visit the United States and her top univerisities, for scientific meetings and exchanges. While the travel is supported by the Japanese agency, this project is intended to support minor cost associated with meetings during the visit to MIT campus. During the visit, scientists from Japan along with MIT professors and young researchers presented their most recent research outcomes and discussed potential avenues of collaboration. On a personal level, many of the participants have the opportunity to meet researchers from the other country, learning about their research and academic culture, and making some new friends. Often, these exchanges lead to more substantial international visits and joint projects and collaboration. While the topic of the meeting was nano-biotechnology, the meeting will also enhance general understanding and goodwill among the scientists in both countries. 

Last year (2013), a total of 17 Japanese scientists visited the US. MIT campus visit was on March 29th, 2013, and the delegation participated in one-day symposium with MIT researchers. There was also a campus facility tour after the lunch, as well as the poster session where scientists from the both countries discussed each other's project in depth.
